column1: The pain often rises in your chest from your stomach.
The stomach contents can irritate the esophagus and cause heartburn and other symptoms.

Medicines that can cause heartburn include: - Anticholinergics (used for sea sickness) - Beta-blockers for high blood pressure or heart disease - Calcium channel blockers for high blood pressure - Dopamine-like drugs for Parkinson disease - Progestin for abnormal menstrual bleeding or birth control - Sedatives for anxiety or sleep problems (insomnia) - Theophylline (for asthma or other lung diseases) - Tricyclic antidepressants Talk to your health care provider if you think one of your medicines may be causing heartburn.
Changing your habits can be helpful in preventing heartburn and other symptoms of GERD.
The following tips will help you avoid heartburn and other GERD symptoms.

First, avoid foods and drinks that can trigger reflux, such as: - Alcohol - Caffeine - Carbonated drinks - Chocolate - Citrus fruits and juices - Peppermint and spearmint - Spicy or fatty foods, full-fat dairy products - Tomatoes and tomato sauces Next, try changing your eating habits: - Avoid bending over or exercising just after eating.
Place books, bricks, or blocks under the legs at the head of your bed.

Sometimes people who think they have heartburn are having a heart attack.
Call your health care provider if: - You have heartburn often or it does not go away after a few weeks of self-care.
Heartburn is easy to diagnose from your symptoms in most cases.

You may need the following tests: - Esophageal motility to measure the pressure of your LES - Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (upper endoscopy) to look at the inside lining of your esophagus and stomach - Upper GI series If your symptoms do not get better with home care, you may need to take medicine to reduce acid that is stronger than over-the-counter medicines.
